title: Alaska (Bernie Marsden) - The Pack (1985)
description:
My reason for buying this was simply to check out just what guitarist Bernie Marsden did next after his departure from Whitesnake.  This album was actually the second and final studio release from the four piece band but thereÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s enough here to tell he still had some prime blues-rock music within him although it does sound on occasions that the band were looking for a hit single too. Owing a fair bit to ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œDriveÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ by The Cars its actually the only certainty IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢d skip if this were on cd.

Positively though, there are four or five very decent blues-rockers on here, all of which you feel could have been candidates for inclusion on a Whitesnake album if Coverdale had decided to stick with the British flavoured sound rather than look for wider spread acceptance.  ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œThe ThingÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ has the nice soft acoustic start before building into a Zeppelin tinged rocker and its side one companion ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œHelp YourselfÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ could also, with a bit of work on the chorus perhaps, have graced any early ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‹Å“Snake album.  The final three offerings of side two are also in the classic blues-rock vein.  Bass guitarist/piano player Brian Badhams solo composition ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œWoman Like YouÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ offers a couple of all too brief solo spots reminding of why Marsden is a respected if un-celebrated guitarist whilst the punchy ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œSchoolgirlÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ and the excellent ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œLove ManÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ reminiscent ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œS.O.S.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ both improve on that, the final track at last offering space for Marsden to really stretch out a bit and shine.

A different direction is taken with the other tracks.  ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œWhere Did They GoÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ has a more American flavoured AOR feel due in a large way to guest saxophonist Billy Paul taking the lead solo.  More surprisingly, although perhaps not given the mid-eighties release, a couple of tracks have more in common with the pomp rockers Magnum.  ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œRun With The PackÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ isnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t a Bad Company cover but is more like a Bryan Adams number with hints of ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œBack Street KidÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½, whilst the synthesiser and big chorus opener ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œI Really Want To KnowÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ is pure Clarkin/Catley country.

In vinyl format especially you canÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t help but notice the cover art.  Credited to one ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œGary Marsh at Clock This LtdÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ he must have given many seconds to considering the band name and thinking ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œIÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢m seeing a snow covered scene hereÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½.  Fortunately the music is better.
